Thanks for the suggestion. I didn't know this exists. Still I think, that =
dependencies should be supported by JUnit out of the box.


--- On Fri, 7/2=
5/08, adrian.kuhn <adrian.kuhn@...> wrote:
From: adrian.kuhn <adrian.=
kuhn@...>
Subject: [junit] Re: Does JUnit 4 now support dependencies?=

To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Date: Friday, July 25, 2008, 7:11 AM










 =
   
            Dear Hans,



have a look at JExample, it extends JUnit wit=
h first-class dependencies. You can declare 

@Depends(... ) which is taken=
 into account when running the test graph. Tests may have 

return values e=
ven, which are injected as parameter to dependent tests.



http://www.iam.=
 unibe.ch/ ~scg/Research/ JExample/



cheers,

Adrian



--- In junit@yaho=
ogroups. com, "hans_schwaebli" <hans_schwaebli@ ...> wrote:

>

> I now thi=
nk that test dependencies are a good idea.

> 

> Does JUnit 4.x support su=
ch dependencies, or if not, is it planned for

> a certain JUnit release to=
 be added?

> 

> For example, if the login test did not work, than all oth=
er tests

> cannot work. They depend on the login test. If login test fails=
, the

> other tests are not executed.

>




      

    
    
	
	 
	
	


=
